The temporal dimensional of each day depends upon the relations among events, moods, and activities, but not predictably. The shape of the days is made by the creation of the list. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Temporal Folds Along a Crisis Line. Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display
author: Johanna Drucker
description: Models of events as temporal folds along a line of crisis. The first is a simple fold, showing an event as a combination of stresses warping a plane. An upper branch of consequences peels off towards an abrupt termination while the lower branch curve back to allow a retrospective view of the event’s unfolding back onto an earlier moment. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Vortex and Fold. Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display
author: Johanna Drucker
description: Two models of an event reaching a crisis with stress factors shown as vectors. The first shows the event as a fold, the second shows it as a vortex. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Parallax. Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display
author: Johanna Drucker
description: A linear model of parallax showing anticipation and retrospective assessment of an event. The “event” is the combination of the moods of the “eye” individual, indicated by the anticipatory arrow and then the retrospective view (lower arrow) across the bar and star that mark a moment and a duration in the temporal span. The event is warped in the retrospective view. The metric might be altered as an effect, though it is not in this depiction. The “eye” is a now-slider, as per the old temporal modeling design, and its position on the bottom line indicates the position of the observer within the course of even. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Changes in Degrees of Anxiety. Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display
author: Johanna Drucker
description: The difference between one state and the next is used to generate a graphical form that is expresses the changes from one moment to another. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Perceived Time. Humanities Approaches to Graphical Display
author: Johanna Drucker
description: The differences between states are projected onto the anxiety and time axes to create a metric that is the effect of perception, rather than an a priri given. By rotating the angles that marked changes of levels of anxiety into a position parallel to the time line, the metrics can be changed as a projection of these lines (whose lengths were generated by a combination of duration and change of intensity of anxiety) onto the temporal axis, thus moving from a “perceived” time to a “projected” time. The result is a set of transformations from an uninflected, supposedly observer independent “time” and “anxiety” to one created as an effect of the experience of time on its expression. Graphic credit Xárene Eskandar.

name: Affective Metrics. Non-representational approaches to modelling interpretation in a graphical environment
author: Johanna Drucker
description: The data structure can hold a simple quantitative value or an expression of value, calculated as a factor of a variable that changes over time, or is calculated to any level of complexity.

name: Layers. Non-representational approaches to modelling interpretation in a graphical environment
author: Johanna Drucker
description: Layers allow information to be brought forward, pushed backward, and changed in tonal value or intensity. Layers are used to distinguish a base layer from the interpretative materials, or, without a base layer, to create a model from scratch. Layers can be used to hold contradictory arguments, varied uses of evidence, to display any aspect of a project that can be articulated independently.

name: Fold. Non-representational approaches to modelling interpretation in a graphical environment
author: Johanna Drucker
description: Fold allows different areas of a model to be brought into connection with each other to see how they relate, what patterns they share and/or make, and what comparisons emerge in the process. Folding is a powerful structuring tool, and making concept models that are multi-dimensional depends on folds, edges, planes, angles, and other geometric principles.

name: Split. Non-representational approaches to modelling interpretation in a graphical environment
author: Johanna Drucker
description: Split is a division within a document, scene, argument, or image to show contradictions within the evidence or rhetorical direction of an argument.

name: Wireframe. Non-representational approaches to modelling interpretation in a graphical environment
author: Johanna Drucker
description: The development of a means of systematically inscribing enunciation in visualizations seems essential to advancing the hermeneutic agenda. The absence of conventions to mark the ‘speaker’ of a visualization, whether it is a display or a model, hampers the development of an approach that acknowledges the discursive modality of visualization.

name: Past Visions. Penned by Frederic William IV
author: Katrin Glinka, Christopher Pietsch and Marian Dörk
description: The drawings by Frederick William IV are part of the collection of prints and drawings of the Prussian Palaces and Gardens Foundation Berlin-Brandenburg and have previously been published in a online inventory catalogue. The visualisation prototype is being developed within the framework of the research project »VIKUS – Visualising Cultural Collections« at the University of Applied Sciences Potsdam.

name: Language DNA: Visualizing a Language Decomposition
author: Adam James Bradley, Travis Kirton, Mark Hancock and Sheelagh Carpendale
description: In the Digital Humanities, there is a fast-growing body of research that uses data visualization to explore the structures of language. While new techniques are proliferating they still fall short of offering whole language experimentation. We provide a mathematical technique that maps words and symbols to ordered unique numerical values, showing that this mapping is one-to-one and onto. We demonstrate this technique through linear, planar, and volumetric visualizations of data sets as large as the Oxford English Dictionary and as small as a single poem. The visualizations of this space have been designed to engage the viewer in the analogic practice of comparison already in use by literary critics but on a scale inaccessible by other means. We studied our visualization with expert participants from many fields including English studies, Information Visualization, Human-Computer Interaction, and Computer Graphics. We present our findings from this study and discuss both the criticisms and validations of our approach.

name: Plastic Pollution
author: Florent Lavergne
description: The accumulation of mismanaged plastic waste in seas and oceans negatively affects marine wildlife. Based on the works of Jambeck, Schmidt et al. (2015, 2017), these infographics depict global trends in waste generation by coastal populations in 2010, with part 1 (blue backgrounds) focusing on mismanaged plastics and part 2 (gold backgrounds) showing a broader picture with several waste categories as well as the most polluted rivers.

name: Death at Home
author: Gabrielle Merite
description: A visual explanation of the 151 femicides that happened in France in 2019.

name: 365 Days of Texting
author: Gabrielle Merite
description: Data can be found in the most unexpected places. As part of my green card application, my partner and I had to prove that our relationship was real or bonafide. Digging through archives of photos, emails, flights, and phone exchanges, I discovered that Google Hangout, the tool we used to most to communicate, gives you access to your entire history of texting. The visualization shows our texts exchanges, each day from Sept 1st 2018 to August 31st, 2019. For each day, the number of characters is indicated and the person who talked the most is displayed. But our relationship is not just based on numbers of characters, it's also a lot of emojis and kind words. To bring the human dimension back to the infographics, I marked by hand, everyday we exchanged "I love you" or Hearts emoji and specific event in our relationship.

name: Keep it Underground
author: GraphicPrototype
description: Data visualization of the increasing amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. This dataviz depicts the increase in fossil fuels combustion and the associated atmospheric C02 concentration.

name: Land Defenders
author: Federica Fragapane
description:
A data visualization on Brazil's land defenders and a map of Brazil showing the deforestation rates, designed for the magazine Atmos.
The visualization shows the average proportion and number of environmental defender deaths in Brazil from 2015-2019 by state. Data provided by Global Witness. Data analysis conducted by Atmos.
The map shows the deforestation rates between 2018-2020 by state, as well as locations mentioned throughout the story. Data by Brazil National Institute for Space Research. The projects have been designed for the article Paid in Blood, piece on Fernando dos Santos Araújo, land rights defender who was killed in the Brazilian state of Pará in January.

name: Slowness
author: Alessia Musio
description:
I look at the sea, breathe iodine, and feel the sun on my skin.  
«I’m not productive», I think. But that it’s all right. How many times have we not felt enough? Enough performing, fit, happy, rich, busy.
But enough for what? For who? My holiday in Croatia was new oxygen mixed with awareness. I let the slowness of those moments get inside me to give a new light to the creativity often stifled by the frenzy. I leave you a fragment of it, along with a wish: live slowly.

name: How Much We Remember
author: Alessia Musio
description: These posters are realized to visualize in a simple and impactful way some small data related to the humans focusing skills.

name: Clip
author: Alessia Musio
description: Clip! it’s a quick dataviz project that I made during the masterclass proposed by @palazzo_grassi and held by @federicafragapane and @marta._foresti. We worked on a dataset related to the Migrants Key Workers’ contribution to the COVID-19 response. I decided to use the clip metaphor because, even though it’s an object that we often take for granted, its function is absolutely fundamental.

name: The Shape of Corporate Inequality
author: Bloomberg Businessweek
description: In the year after the Black Lives Matter protests, many US corporations promised to improve their record on diversity. Bloomberg obtained EEO-1 forms from 37 of the nation's 100 biggest companies, showing the race breakdown of workers across job categories. Reading from left to right, we often see the strong presence of Black and Hispanic workers in what are considered non- and semi-skilled professions become smaller or disappear as we reach the managerial and executive ranks for individual companies. Reading down, we can see how disproportionately Black and Hispanic workers are concentrated in non-managerial positions across the board.

name: Architectural Association School of Architecture
author: Yaqi Tang and Zhibang Jiang
description: This visualization provides a website platform for users interested in the art of architecture or working in the art industry to gain an in-depth and comprehensive understanding of the AA Architectural League, information on the outstanding architects who have graduated from AA, and the network of relationships that exist among architects.

name: Elemental Flows
author: Nadieh Bremer
description: For this collection I combined elements of generative art and data art. Each piece uses the same underlying flow algorithm, but I’ve fine-tuned each to look like the element I’m trying to convey. I went with the elements of Earth, Water, Air, Sun. Yes, Sun instead of Fire because (perhaps as an Astronomer) I think sunlight is a far more necessary element than fire. Finally, as an “extra” element I added Digital, since many people wouldn’t/couldn’t live without this being part of their lives. For all pieces, except Digital, I’ve added data relevant to the element as “obstacles” in the flows. Tree density for Earth, rainfall for Water, air quality for Air, and sunshine hours for Sun. Each of the pieces has been sold as an NFT on Foundation.

name: What Scientists Have Learnt from 100 Years of Bird Banding
author: Jan Willem Tulp
description: In celebration of 100 years of bird banding, Scientific American (Jen Christiansen) commissioned me to create a visualization for the March 2021 edition. The Bird Banding Laboratory has been curating bird banding records since 1920. In 1959 a fire damaged many of the records, which helped to drive a shift toward electronic record keeping. For practical reasons, most research projects today deal with the digitized records, starting with birds first banded or reencountered after 1960. This visualization shows the birds that lie at the heart of the digitized data: 70,593,588 banding records and 4,134,060 reencounter records from 1960 through 2016. Two visualizations have been created, the first one shows the number of birds banded over time for the various categories of birds (with beautiful illustrations by Liz Wahid) of the most common bird in each category. A second visualization shows 4 globes, one for each seasons, indicating where and how many birds were banded, including a special note of the a bird that has the longest travel.

name: One Year Connected
author: Alberto Molina Arce
description: For Christmas 2019, I made a postcard with a personalized graphic in which I showed all the friends and family and the distance that separates us through lines. Each postcard was personalized indicating which line was the recipient and the distance. A way to celebrate getting together, somehow.

name: UAE's Global Innovation Index
author: Arohi Bangera
description: The Global Innovation Index provides an innovation ranking for 130 economies. It is a leading reference for innovation and a tool for action for most economies. The UAE ranked 33rd in 2021’s index. Below is a data portrait of all the variables that make the index, highlighting score and rank, as of 2021.

name: Information and Violence
author: Siori Kitajima
description: Information and Violence is an interactive data visualization showing a timeline of major U.S. news headlines along with monthly gun sales and homicides counts from 2016 to 2021. Since 2016, the number of gun sales and homicides has been steadily increasing. By showing them along top news at the time, it could show the possibility of the psychological influence of fear and anxiety in society.

name: 100 Days of Protests Rock Hong Kong
author: South China Morning Post
description: The pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong during 2019 represent a milestone in the city's history and a breaking point between the situation prior to the anti-Beijing movements and what would happen later with the crackdown of the Chinese authority to suffocate all demonstrations through the enactment of the National Security Law. The protests continued to evolve, going from being massive and very peaceful, turning into violent events in the space of 3 or 4 months, that is what is sought to be consigned in this visual piece.

name: Days and Nights
author: Krisztina Szücs
description: This data visualization gallery shows the sunrise and sunset times around the world. See how the night and daylight areas change during a two year period. To focus on the length of nights the y axis for hours starts at noon.

name: Songbird Connections
author: Alli Torban
description: Researchers studied how many times various North American Songbirds fed at the same feeder at the same time. I visualized this data by connecting the birds spotted feeding at the same time. The dots are sized by the number of times a bird was spotted eating with another bird. It's sorted to reduce the number of arc overlaps. The resulting artistic network and styling are a nod to a bird feather. It's clear that one bird in particular really liked to dine with company!

name: Spotting Minard on the Corner Three
author: Senthil Natarajan
description: Have you heard of the term "moonshot?" The concept of seeking out 10x solutions that have extraordinarily high barriers to overcome? Imagine how DeAndre Jordan, professional basketball player for over a decade, feels every time he steps onto the free throw line. Over his entire career, he has made, and I actually had to fact check this, fewer than 50% of his free throws. Every time he goes to the line, he’s throwing up literal and figurative moonshots. Just imagine if Christoph Scheiner had been around as a basketball fan in the 21st century. Instead of mapping the progressions of celestial bodies and sunspots, he may have instead mapped DeAndre Jordan free throws.

name: 5 Years
author: Camilla De Amicis
description:
“5Years” Project by Camilla De Amicis, the project is a data visualisation summarising five years of a love story.
The idea starts from an awareness of the traces that are left spatially by living experiences together on a daily basis. The relationship between the two, being at a distance, has led the couple to experience different cities and places, some more frequently than others. Each coloured macro shape represents a city, the name of which is deliberately left unstated so that only the couple can trace the specific locations. Instead, the dark dots on the spots trace the position of the exact locations on the city map locally. Each experience was distinguished on the basis of type (whether or not related to a culinary event) and the type of memory associated with the experience. In this case, data collection is based on the experience and mental reconstruction and through traces (photographs, items saved on online maps, notes) of one of the two members of the pair. The approach to data visualisation in this case becomes personal and deliberately subjective, in order to create an emotional narrative through data that blends a humanistic vision with a more technical and spatially faithful one.

name: Kollisionen
author: Sara Akhlaq, Arran Ridley, Mark-Jan Bludau, Marian Dörk
description: The KOLLISIONEN project studies the potential of immersion and narration for the visualization of cultural heritage collections and conceives novel interaction and visualization techniques for cultural collections. This interdisciplinary research is carried out in close collaboration with film scholars and creative technologists at Film University Babelsberg and is funded by the European Regional Development Fund.

name: Not My Cup of Coffee
author: Cedric Scherer
description: The visualization shows the distribution of coffee bean ratings by the Coffee Quality Institute for countries with 25 or more reviews (up to 2018). Distributions are shown as dot plots and multiple interval stripes. The chart highlights that the median and highscore per country are quite similar but the score of the worst coffee beans differs a lot.

name: From Plastic Into Data
author: Yannan Ning
description: This 4 in 1 journalism, designed in 2020 and launched in 2021, reflects the severe situation of global plastic pollution in the past 10 years since 2010 and gives its prediction by 2025 based on the data from Our World in Data published in 2017. For a distinct story telling clue, this project divides the dataset into 4 chapters by using different sea-animal like metaphors in each and analysing the situation from plastic emission, generation, classification, and distribution step by step.

name: Together
author: Kirell Benzi
description: The organizational chart is a business necessity, and normally the furthest thing from a description of business culture. This artwork visualizes the hierarchical positions of employees of the Havas group, a multinational public relations, and media company. After many attempts, I realized that regular dataviz was not enough and turned to data art. "Together" radically changes from traditional radial visualizations for hierarchies. I thought it was more interesting to evoke professional growth from within a company, with the top management rooted in the earth and the thousands of colleagues rising up, organically growing like thousands of flowers.

name: Ease Getting Electricity
author: University of the Arts London
description: Joyful Data is a tool for making custom data-driven graphics in a live, interactive editor. It narrows the gap for non-programmers to create bespoke visualisations while maintaining design control. Joyful Data is built on top of Joy.js, a wonderful library by Nicky Case. The project page (https://priti.is/makingjoyfuldata) talks about the concept in more detail & highlights some responses from the community. This was an independent project I created in January 2020 as part of Gramener's Storylabs team (https://gramener.com/storylabs/).

name: Dear Data. Doors' Patterns
author: Stefanie Posavec and Giorgia Lupi
description: Dear Data is a postcard collection capturing the everyday life on personal data. Inspired by data designer Giorgia Lupi and Stefanie Posavec, Pat and I visualized data in an analog hand-drawn way. For four months we got to know each other through data. Ea
